title.narrative: FAO & UNICEF stöd till familjer som drabbats av torkan i Guatemala år 2014.
FAO & UNICEF support to families affected by drought 2014 in Guatemala.

description.narrative: Dry Corridor Joint Program aims to recover the livelihoods of small-scale family farmers of subsistence and infrasubsistence affected by 2014 drought in two communities of Jalapa (San Pedro Pinula and San Luis Jilotepeque) and three of Chiquimula (Camotán, Jocotán and Chiquimula). The program provides low cost technologies for food security adapted to drought, technical assistance to manage and prepare the small-scale farmers plots to better face droughts, increase their yields to promote food security. The program works closely to families, farmers organizations and municipalities through information and training to promote integrated micro-watershed management.

Guatemala har upplevt en förlängd period av torka under 2014, vilket har påverkan främst i de nordöstra delarna av landet och det område som kallas "den torra korridoren". Torkan har särskilt påverkat personer i fattigdom och extremfattigdom som är beroende av jordbruk för deras uppehälle. Guatemalas regering förklarade katastroftillstånd i de drabbade departementen och framförde en vädjan om humanitärt bistånd. Regeringen lanserade också en plan bistå befolkningen som drabbats. Planen omfattar tre strategier: 1) humanitärt bistånd, 2) återhämtning av försörjningsmöjligheter och 3) motståndskraft och anpassning till klimatförändringar. FN systemet i Guatemala presenterade en omgripande plan som svar på regeringens förfrågan om stöd. Detta projekt är baserat på FAO och UNICEFs föreslagna roller på medel- och långsikt i den planen. Projektet är därmed i linje med Guatemalas regeringsplan för bistånd på medellång och lång sikt: 2) återhämtning av försörjningsmöjligheter och 3) motståndskraft och anpassning till klimatförändringar. Projektansökan är för en period på två år och budgeten är på 20 MSEK. Initiativet syftar till att återställa försörjningsmöjligheter för de familjer som drabbats av den långvariga torkan under 2014, samt skapa motståndskraft hos dem genom metoder för handhålland och bevarande av jord och vatten i kommuner i regionerna Chiquimula och Jalapa.

Guatemala has experienced a prolonged drought during 2014 affecting the north east of the country. The drought has particularly affected smallholder farmers with subsistence and infra subsistence production in the area known as the dry corridor. The Guatemalan government declared a state of emergency in the affected departments and submitted an appeal for humanitarian aid. The government, through its Council of Nutrition and Food Security, SESAN (for its acronym in Spanish), has recognized the damages caused by the extended drought. This led to the government declaring State of Public Calamity in the departments affected and made an appeal for humanitarian assistance. The government also launched a plan to attend the population affected that includes three strategies: 1) humanitarian assistance, 2) livelihoods recovery and 3) resilience and adaptation to climate change. The United Nations system in Guatemala presented a response plan in reaction to the government's request for support. This project is based on the proposed roles for FAO and UNICEF in the medium and long term of the plan. The project is therefore in line with the Guatemalan government plan for the assistance in the medium and long term: 2) recovery of livelihoods and 3) the resilience and adaptation to climate change. The project application is for a period of two years and a budget of 20 MSEK. The contribution aims to recover the livelihoods of the families affected by prolonged drought of 2014, as well as, to create resilience through management and conservation of soil and water in Chiquimula and Jalapa.

description.narrative: - Implementation of climate-adapted practices that improved the productive capacity of the families in the milpa (traditional multicrop field), through which their production of maize and beans doubled. As a result, by the end of the project, 2 424 families have maize reserves and 5 715 have a six-month reserve of beans. - Implementation of climate-adapted practices that improved the productive capacity of families in the home. By the end of the project, a total of 6 766 families (96 percent) have improved their diets by making them more varied, and have increased the availability and their consumption of plant and animal protein. - Implementation of rainwater harvesting infrastructure, validating rainwater harvesting methodologies and implementing six models. A total of 6 413 families now store and have available 16 million litres of water in their homes for agricultural production, human consumption and domestic use. - Investments in soil improvement, so that most rainwater is stored and absorbed in the micro-watersheds. Families implemented minimum tillage practices, terracing, ditches and living barriers, the SAF Kuxur rum agroforestry system, dead barriers and drainage ditches, among other elements. - Promotion of business ventures to improve incomes and thus enable the purchase of food. By the end of the project a total of 3 109 families (44 percent) belonging to 22 enterprise groups had generated income of 12.5 million quetzals (GTQ) between 2015 and 2021. Of this amount, GTQ 124 000 is managed under the contingency mutual funds methodology.
